topics.title: Laptop will not power on
topics.reply:
Work through these checks to wake the laptop:
1. Disconnect the charger and accessories, then hold the power button for 15 seconds to drain static. Plug the charger directly into a wall outlet.
2. Confirm charger and laptop lights. If none appear, try a different outlet or adapter. Reseat removable batteries.
3. Force a reset:
   - Windows or Chromebook: hold the power button for about 20 seconds.
   - Apple silicon MacBook: hold Power until the text "Loading Options" appears.
   - Intel MacBook: press Shift + Control + Option + Power for 10 seconds, then release and tap Power once.
4. If fans spin but the screen stays dark, connect an external display or shine a flashlight at the panel to spot a backlight issue.
5. Still stuck? Note any lights or beeps, check warranty status, and plan a repair visit.

plan.rationale: Clears static build-up and verifies charger health.
Overrides firmware hangs common across vendors.
Warranty or repair teams need accurate notes.

topics.title: Laptop battery drains fast
topics.reply:
Improve battery life with this routine:
1. Check health: on Windows run "powercfg /batteryreport" or open Settings > System > Power. On macOS option-click the battery icon. Replace packs below 80 percent health.
2. Update BIOS or firmware using the vendor utility (Lenovo Vantage, Dell Command, HP Support Assistant, ASUS Armoury Crate).
3. Turn on battery saver or low power mode, enable adaptive brightness, and close background apps. On macOS, disable Power Nap if you do not need it.
4. Calibrate monthly: charge to 100 percent, drain to roughly 10 percent, then charge back to full without interruption.

plan.rationale: Shows whether hardware needs replacement.
Vendors patch power bugs frequently.
Reduces drain from background tasks.

topics.title: Windows update stuck or failing
topics.reply:
Repair Windows Update with these steps:
1. Restart, plug the computer into power, and rerun Windows Update (Settings > Windows Update). Allow 15 minutes.
2. Run the Windows Update troubleshooter (Settings > System > Troubleshoot > Other troubleshooters).
3. Clear the SoftwareDistribution cache. Open Command Prompt as administrator and run:
   net stop wuauserv
   net stop bits
   del /s /q %windir%\\SoftwareDistribution\\*
   net start wuauserv
   net start bits
4. Restart and try again. For stubborn feature updates, download the Windows Update Assistant and perform an in-place upgrade.

plan.rationale: Reloads pending services cleanly.
Fixes corrupted update files automatically.
Installs the latest build without data loss.

topics.title: Mac running slow or hot
topics.reply:
Speed up your Mac:
1. Boot into Safe Mode (hold Shift at startup), log in, then restart normally to clear caches.
2. Open Activity Monitor (Applications > Utilities) and sort by CPU or Memory to find runaway apps. Force quit offenders.
3. Update macOS (System Settings > General > Software Update) and free space until at least 15 GB remains.
4. Reset NVRAM or PRAM (Option + Command + P + R at startup) and, for Intel Macs, reset the SMC (Shift + Control + Option + Power for 10 seconds).

plan.rationale: Clears caches and isolates problematic login items.
Highlights resource hogs quickly.
Keeps firmware and macOS stable.

topics.title: iPhone or iPad misbehaving
topics.reply:
Quick iOS or iPadOS fixes:
1. Force restart: press Volume Up, then Volume Down, then hold the Side button until the Apple logo appears. Older devices use Home + Power.
2. Install pending updates (Settings > General > Software Update) and review battery health (Settings > Battery).
3. If apps keep crashing, reinstall them or reset all settings (Settings > General > Transfer or Reset > Reset all settings).
4. For charging issues, gently clean the Lightning or USB-C port, swap the cable, and test a different wall charger.

plan.rationale: Clears firmware hiccups without data loss.
Ensures the OS and hardware remain healthy.
Removes corrupted preferences while keeping data.

topics.title: Android phone or tablet issues
topics.reply:
Try this Android rescue path:
1. Force restart by holding Power + Volume Down for about 20 seconds.
2. Clear the cache of misbehaving apps (Settings > Apps > App > Storage > Clear cache) and install system updates.
3. Boot into Safe Mode (hold Power, then press and hold "Power off" and confirm). If the problem disappears, uninstall recently added apps.
4. For charging trouble, clean the USB-C port, swap the cable and brick, and enable optimized charging where available.

plan.rationale: Eliminates temporary software glitches.
Identifies problematic third-party apps.
Confirms the hardware delivering power is working.

topics.title: Home Wi-Fi problems
topics.reply:
Bring Wi-Fi back online:
1. Power cycle the modem, router, and mesh nodes. Unplug for 30 seconds, plug in the modem first, wait for solid lights, then power the router or nodes.
2. If only one device struggles, forget and reconnect to the network, confirming the correct password and security type.
3. Update router firmware, then set channels (1, 6, or 11 for 2.4 GHz; DFS or less crowded channels for 5 GHz).
4. Move the router to a central, elevated spot and add mesh nodes or an extender for dead zones.

plan.rationale: Clears ISP, DHCP, and routing hiccups.
Refreshes credentials and IP assignments.
Reduces interference and improves range.

topics.title: Printer or scanner not working
topics.reply:
Get the printer back online:
1. Power cycle the printer and the device you are printing from. Confirm they share the same Wi-Fi or that the USB cable is secure.
2. Clear the print queue, then reinstall the printer through the vendor utility (HP Smart, Epson Connect, Canon IJ, Brother iPrint&Scan).
3. Run maintenance tools such as nozzle clean or alignment and print a test page.
4. On Windows, if the printer is offline, open Settings > Bluetooth & devices > Printers, turn off "Let Windows manage my default printer," and pick the correct device manually.

plan.rationale: Clears stalled print jobs and handshake issues.
Ensures compatibility with OS updates.
Fixes clogged heads and verifies output.

topics.title: Email setup or login trouble
topics.reply:
Follow this email setup checklist:
1. Confirm the password in webmail first so you know it works.
2. Use automatic setup in the mail app. If it fails, switch to manual and enter:
   Gmail: IMAP imap.gmail.com (SSL 993), SMTP smtp.gmail.com (SSL 465 or TLS 587).
   Outlook / Hotmail: IMAP outlook.office365.com (SSL 993), SMTP smtp.office365.com (TLS 587).
   Yahoo: IMAP imap.mail.yahoo.com (SSL 993), SMTP smtp.mail.yahoo.com (SSL 465).
3. If multi-factor authentication is enabled, generate an app password or approve the sign-in from your authenticator app.

plan.rationale: Avoids chasing setup errors caused by typos.
Ensures the client talks to the right IMAP and SMTP endpoints.
Providers block logins without trusted codes.

topics.title: App or game keeps crashing
topics.reply:
Stabilize the software:
1. Update the app and operating system. Many crash fixes come through updates.
2. Clear cache or preferences. Windows: Settings > Apps > App > Advanced options > Reset. macOS: remove the app plist file in ~/Library/Preferences (after backing it up).
3. Disable add-ins or extensions to isolate conflicts.
4. Update graphics, audio, and chipset drivers, especially if crashes began after a system update.

plan.rationale: Patch releases often resolve crashes.
Removes corrupted settings and data files.
Conflicting plugins or drivers trigger many failures.

topics.title: Backup and recovery guidance
topics.reply:
Keep data safe even offline:
1. Enable built-in backups. Windows: File History or a scheduled Macrium Reflect job. macOS: Time Machine on an external drive.
2. Clone important drives to an external SSD or HDD every month and store a copy offsite or in a fire-resistant safe.
3. Test restores quarterly by recovering a random document to confirm the backups work.

plan.rationale: Delivers quick protection with minimal setup.
Protects against ransomware or hardware failure.
Confirms backups can actually be used.

generic.title: General troubleshooting checklist
generic.reply:
Here is a reliable checklist that works offline:
1. Restart the affected device and any connected hardware (routers, docks, accessories). Many problems clear after a full power cycle.
2. Install pending system, driver, and app updates whenever possible. Keep at least 15 percent storage free.
3. Record error codes, event logs, or indicator lights and take photos so you have proof if you need to escalate.
4. Back up important data before trying more advanced fixes. Share your notes with Garin if you need hands-on help.

plan.rationale: Resets state across hardware and software.
Out-of-date software and full drives cause many issues.
Evidence speeds up professional repair.
